oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Geo. R. Calhoun & Company and Lebeck Bros. advertisements, featured in the Yearbook “Salmagundi,” of the Boscobel College for Young Ladies, Nashville, Tennessee, 1907
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The Geo. R. Calhoun & Co. (Fifth Ave. corner Union) and Lebeck Bros. (Church Street) advertisements featured in the 1907 Boscobel College for Young Ladies yearbook. This manufacturing and importing house furnishing business sold products such as “stoves, hollowware, glassware, china, tinware, mantels and grates, refrigerators, freezers, sewing machines, toys, etc.” The Boscobel College for Young Ladies was a college in East Nashville, founded in 1889 as the Nashville Baptist Female College by the Tennessee Baptist Convention. The college operated for twenty-five years--until 1914. The campus was built around an East Nashville mansion, formerly owned by Anna Shelby Williams. The mansion stood atop a tree-covered hill overlooking the Cumberland River. The campus covered ten wooded acres on Sevier Street near South Seventh Street (then called Foster Street), south of Sylvan Street. In 1918, the property became home to the National Baptist Seminary and Missionary Training School, which functioned until 1931. The buildings were razed in 1940. Forms part of the yearbook collection: Boscobel College, “Salmagundi,” 1907. 1 volume
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Boscobel College (Nashville, Tenn.); Lebeck Brothers (Nashville, Tenn.); George R. Calhoun & Co. (Nashville, Tenn.)
